assessment.name: Mental Health Self-Assessment
assessment.description: This comprehensive assessment uses GAD-7 and PHQ-9 questionnaires along with lifestyle factors to evaluate your mental wellbeing. It is private, confidential, and designed to help you reflect on your overall health.
assessment.disclaimer: This assessment is for informational purposes only and does not replace professional medical advice. If you're experiencing severe symptoms, please consult a healthcare professional.

questions.text: Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge?
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by not being able to stop or control worrying?
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by worrying too much about different things?
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by trouble relaxing?
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by being so restless that it is hard to sit still?
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by becoming easily annoyed or irritable?
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by feeling afraid as if something awful might happen?
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by little interest or pleasure in doing things?
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by feeling down, depressed, or hopeless?
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much?
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by feeling tired or having little energy?
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by poor appetite or overeating?
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by feeling bad about yourself, or that you are a failure or have let yourself or your family down?
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television?

Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have noticed? Or the opposite - being so fidgety or restless that you have been moving around a lot more than usual?
Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by thoughts that you would be better off dead, or of hurting yourself in some way?
On average, how many hours of sleep do you get per night?
Do you feel refreshed after waking up?
How would you rate your overall diet quality?
Do you feel you have someone you can talk to when feeling stressed or sad?
How connected do you feel with family or friends?
How often do you engage in social activities or spend time with others?
How often do you feel overwhelmed by your work or studies?
Do you find it difficult to balance responsibilities (work, school, personal life)?
How satisfied are you with your current work or study situation?
Do you experience physical symptoms such as headaches, stomach issues, or muscle tension when stressed?
How often do you exercise or engage in physical activity?
How would you rate your overall physical health?
When feeling low or anxious, do you use healthy coping strategies (like journaling, meditation, or hobbies)?
Do you rely on substances (alcohol, nicotine, drugs) when stressed?
How confident do you feel in your ability to handle stress and difficult situations?
Do you often feel restless or find it hard to stay still? (Consistency check)
Do you struggle with sleep quality, either too little or too much? (Consistency check)

0-4.description: Your anxiety levels appear to be minimal. This suggests you're managing stress well.

5-9.description: You may be experiencing mild anxiety. Consider stress management techniques.

10-14.description: You're experiencing moderate anxiety. Consider speaking with a healthcare professional.

15-21.description: You're experiencing severe anxiety. We strongly recommend consulting a healthcare professional.

0-4.description: Your mood appears to be stable with minimal signs of depression.

5-9.description: You may be experiencing mild depression. Consider lifestyle changes and support.

10-14.description: You're experiencing moderate depression. Consider professional support.

15-19.description: You're experiencing moderately severe depression. Professional help is recommended.

20-27.description: You're experiencing severe depression. Please seek immediate professional help.

low_risk: Continue maintaining your current healthy habits
Maintain social connections and support networks
Keep up with regular exercise and good sleep hygiene
moderate_risk: Consider speaking with a counselor or therapist
Implement stress reduction techniques like deep breathing
Prioritize sleep and establish a regular sleep schedule
Connect with supportive friends and family
high_risk: Seek professional help from a mental health provider
Contact a crisis helpline if you're having thoughts of self-harm
Reach out to trusted friends, family, or support groups
Consider medication evaluation with a healthcare provider
Establish safety plans and coping strategies

confidence_logic.note: Confidence score is calculated based on response consistency, completion rate, and response time patterns.
